0.name: Apple — Apple scab
0.description: Fungal disease causing olive-brown spots on leaves and fruit; can lead to distortion and drop.
0.solution: Prune for airflow, remove infected debris, apply protective fungicides at early season if needed.

1.name: Apple — Black rot
1.description: Fungal disease causing leaf spots and fruit rot; concentric rings on fruit.
1.solution: Prune out cankers, remove mummified fruit, use copper or labeled fungicides when appropriate.

2.name: Apple — Cedar apple rust
2.description: Orange rust spots on apple leaves due to Gymnosporangium; lifecycle alternates with junipers.
2.solution: Remove nearby junipers if possible; apply protective fungicides during spring infection period.

3.name: Apple — healthy
3.description: Leaf appears healthy with no visible disease symptoms.
3.solution: Maintain good nutrition and sanitation; continue regular monitoring.

4.name: Blueberry — healthy
4.description: Leaf appears healthy with no visible disease symptoms.
4.solution: Maintain good nutrition and sanitation; continue regular monitoring.

5.name: Cherry (including sour) — Powdery mildew
5.description: White powdery fungal growth on leaf surfaces; can cause curling and reduced vigor.
5.solution: Improve airflow, avoid overhead irrigation, and apply sulfur or other labeled fungicides.

6.name: Cherry (including sour) — healthy
6.description: Leaf appears healthy with no visible disease symptoms.
6.solution: Maintain good nutrition and sanitation; continue regular monitoring.

7.name: Corn (maize) — Cercospora leaf spot Gray leaf spot
7.description: Rectangular gray lesions bounded by veins; reduces photosynthesis and yield.
7.solution: Rotate crops, use resistant hybrids, manage residue, and consider fungicide at tasseling if severe.

8.name: Corn (maize) — Common rust
8.description: Reddish-brown pustules on both leaf surfaces caused by Puccinia sorghi.
8.solution: Use resistant hybrids; fungicides only if severe and susceptible variety at early stages.

9.name: Corn (maize) — Northern Leaf Blight
9.description: Long cigar-shaped gray-green lesions; can coalesce and blight leaves.
9.solution: Plant resistant hybrids, rotate crops, manage residue; fungicide based on risk and growth stage.

10.name: Corn (maize) — healthy
10.description: Leaf appears healthy with no visible disease symptoms.
10.solution: Maintain good nutrition and sanitation; continue regular monitoring.

11.name: Grape — Black rot
11.description: Circular leaf spots with dark margins; fruit shrivels into black mummies.
11.solution: Remove mummies and infected shoots; apply protective sprays from pre-bloom through fruit set.

12.name: Grape — Esca (Black Measles)
12.description: Tiger-striping on leaves; berries may develop black spots and shrivel.
12.solution: Prune out infected wood, avoid trunk injuries, and improve vine vigor; no curative sprays.

13.name: Grape — Leaf blight (Isariopsis Leaf Spot)
13.description: Irregular brown lesions on leaves; may defoliate under humid conditions.
13.solution: Improve canopy airflow; remove infected leaves; use labeled fungicides if needed.

14.name: Grape — healthy
14.description: Leaf appears healthy with no visible disease symptoms.
14.solution: Maintain good nutrition and sanitation; continue regular monitoring.

15.name: Orange — Haunglongbing (Citrus greening)
15.description: Serious bacterial disease causing blotchy mottle, yellow shoots, small misshapen fruit.
15.solution: Control psyllid vector, remove infected trees where mandated, use clean planting material.

16.name: Peach — Bacterial spot
16.description: Angular leaf spots and fruit blemishes; caused by Xanthomonas.
16.solution: Plant tolerant cultivars, avoid overhead irrigation, apply copper/bactericides per label.

17.name: Peach — healthy
17.description: Leaf appears healthy with no visible disease symptoms.
17.solution: Maintain good nutrition and sanitation; continue regular monitoring.

18.name: Pepper, bell — Bacterial spot
18.description: Water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruit that turn dark and scabby.
18.solution: Use certified seed/transplants, copper plus mancozeb rotations, avoid handling when wet.

19.name: Pepper, bell — healthy
19.description: Leaf appears healthy with no visible disease symptoms.
19.solution: Maintain good nutrition and sanitation; continue regular monitoring.

20.name: Potato — Early blight
20.description: Concentric-ring lesions starting on older leaves; caused by Alternaria.
20.solution: Rotate crops, avoid stress, and apply protectant fungicides starting at row closure if needed.

21.name: Potato — Late blight
21.description: Water-soaked lesions with white sporulation at margins under cool, wet conditions.
21.solution: Use certified seed, destroy cull piles, apply systemic + protectant fungicides under high risk.

22.solution: Maintain good nutrition and sanitation; continue regular monitoring.

25.name: Squash — Powdery mildew
25.description: White powdery patches on cucurbit leaves and stems; reduces vigor.
25.solution: Plant tolerant varieties, improve airflow, and apply sulfur or other labeled fungicides early.

26.name: Strawberry — Leaf scorch
26.description: Small purplish spots that coalesce into scorched areas; usually cosmetic but can reduce vigor.
26.solution: Remove old leaves post-harvest, improve airflow, and use labeled fungicides if severe.

27.name: Strawberry — healthy
27.description: Leaf appears healthy with no visible disease symptoms.
27.solution: Maintain good nutrition and sanitation; continue regular monitoring.

28.name: Tomato — Bacterial spot
28.description: Small water-soaked leaf spots and fruit specks; thrives in warm, wet weather.
28.solution: Use disease-free seed/transplants, copper-based sprays, avoid working plants when wet.

29.name: Tomato — Early blight
29.description: Concentric target-like lesions on lower leaves; defoliation common.
29.solution: Mulch to reduce splash, prune lower leaves, rotate, and use protectant fungicides.

30.name: Tomato — Late blight
30.description: Rapid blighting with pale green to brown lesions and white sporulation in cool, moist conditions.
30.solution: Remove infected plants, avoid overhead irrigation, and apply appropriate fungicides promptly.

31.name: Tomato — Leaf Mold
31.description: Olive-green velvety growth on undersides of leaves in humid greenhouses.
31.solution: Increase ventilation, reduce humidity, water at base, and use labeled fungicides.

32.name: Tomato — Septoria leaf spot
32.description: Numerous small circular spots with dark margins and light centers on lower leaves.
32.solution: Remove infected leaves, improve airflow, rotate, and apply protectant fungicides.

33.name: Tomato — Spider mites Two-spotted spider mite
33.description: Tiny mites cause stippling, bronzing, and fine webbing; thrive in hot, dry conditions.
33.solution: Spray water to reduce dust, introduce predators, use miticides if necessary.

34.name: Tomato — Target Spot
34.description: Brown lesions with concentric rings leading to defoliation, often in humid tropics.
34.solution: Improve airflow, avoid leaf wetness, and apply labeled fungicides.

35.name: Tomato — Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus
35.description: Virus causes upward leaf curling, yellowing, and stunted growth; transmitted by whiteflies.
35.solution: Manage whiteflies (nets, mulches, insecticides), remove infected plants, use tolerant varieties.

36.name: Tomato — Tomato mosaic virus
36.description: Mosaic mottling and leaf distortion; virus spreads by contact/contaminated tools.
36.solution: Sanitize tools, avoid tobacco handling, use resistant varieties; no cure—remove infected plants.

37.name: Tomato — healthy
37.description: Leaf appears healthy with no visible disease symptoms.
37.solution: Maintain good nutrition and sanitation; continue regular monitoring.
